findings.title: ST - Stops Transactions
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to stop sales for all users excluding the owner by setting `_maxTxAmount` to zero, potentially operating as a honeypot.

findings.title: ELFM - Exceeds Fees Limit
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to increase over the allowed limit of 25%. The owner may take advantage of it by calling the `setTaxFeePercent` function with a high percentage value.

findings.title: UFV - Unchecked Fee Value
findings.description: The contract's fee logic overlooks the value of `_BurnFee` when `takeFee` is set to `false`, leading to users paying a burn fee even when no fees are intended.

findings.title: MC - Missing Check
findings.description: The contract is processing variables that have not been properly sanitized and checked that they form the proper shape, leading to potential vulnerability issues.

findings.title: PVC - Price Volatility Concern
findings.description: The contract accumulates tokens from taxes to swap them for ETH, but the variable `numTokensSellToAddToLiquidity` is set to a fixed value equal to the total supply, which can lead to significant price volatility due to token price fluctuations.

findings.title: MAU - Misleading Address Usage
findings.description: The contract contains the `_burnWalletAddress` variable, which misleadingly suggests it represents a conventional burn address, but is actually initialized with a wallet address and used within the `_takeBurn` function, potentially leading to unintended behaviors and misinterpretation of the contract's token burn mechanism.

findings.title: FRV - Fee Restoration Vulnerability
findings.description: The contract demonstrates a potential vulnerability upon removing and restoring the fees. This can occur when the fees have been set to zero, leading to unintended consequences such as incorrect fee calculations or unexpected behavior within the contract.

findings.title: FSA - Fixed Swap Address
findings.description: The swap address is assigned once and cannot be changed, which may prevent the contract from migrating to a new liquidity pool pair or decentralized exchange.

findings.title: RSW - Redundant Storage Writes
findings.description: The contract modifies the state of variables without checking if their current value is the same as the one given as an argument, leading to redundant storage writes and unnecessary gas consumption.

findings.title: RED - Redudant Event Declaration
findings.description: The event `MinTokensBeforeSwapUpdated` is declared and not being used in the contract, making it redundant.

findings.title: RSML - Redundant SafeMath Library
findings.description: The usage of the SafeMath library adds complexity, overhead and increases gas consumption unnecessarily since Solidity versions greater than or equal to 0.8.0 have native functionality for arithmetic operations that revert to underflow and overflow.

findings.title: L02 - State Variables could be Declared Constant
findings.description: State variables can be declared as constant using the constant keyword to ensure their values cannot be changed after being set and decrease gas consumption.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The code does not adhere to the Solidity naming conventions, which can affect readability and maintainability.

findings.title: L07 - Missing Events Arithmetic
findings.description: Events are a way to record and log information about changes or actions that occur within a contract. They are often used to notify external parties or clients about events that have occurred within the contract, such as the transfer of tokens or the completion of a task.

findings.title: L09 - Dead Code Elimination
findings.description: Dead code can make a contract more difficult to understand and maintain, and can also increase the size of the contract and the cost of deploying and interacting with it.

findings.title: L17 - Usage of Solidity Assembly
findings.description: Using assembly can be error-prone and requires careful testing and debugging to ensure correctness.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity that is compatible with the specified version (i.e., any version that is a higher minor or patch version) can be used to compile the contract. The version lock is a mechanism that allows the author to specify a minimum version of the Solidity compiler that must be used to compile the contract code.
